snippet: Major earthquakes have hit southern California more often than thought, providing additional evidence the region is overdue for a so-called Big One on the San Andreas fault, geologists say.    Their study found that over the last 500 years, five q...
lead_paragraph: Major earthquakes have hit southern California more often than thought, providing additional evidence the region is overdue for a so-called Big One on the San Andreas fault, geologists say. Their study found that over the last 500 years, five quakes measuring 7 to 8.3 on the Richter scale ruptured the San Bernardino Mountains segment of the fault near Wrightwood, north of San Bernardino.
